resources.string: Jacques Marchais Museum of Tibetan Art
The Empire State Building became the tallest building in New York City again after the collapse of the World Trade Center in 2001.
The American Museum of Natural History occupies more than 186,000 square meters (2,000,000 square feet). It is one of the largest museums in the world.
At 541 meters (1,776 feet), One World Trade Center is the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere, and the sixth-tallest in the world.
The world famous ball drops from a pole atop the 25-story One Times Square building and the ball is timed to reach the bottom of the pole at precisely 12 midnight, New Year’s Day.
It occupies one of the few remaining structures from the 1964 New York World\'s Fair, and is New York City's only hands-on science and technology center.
Flushing Meadows–Corona Park was created as the site of the 1939/1940 New York World\'s Fair and also hosted the 1964/1965 New York World's Fair.
The stadium was built as a replacement for and adjacent to Shea Stadium, which opened in 1964 next to the site of the 1964 New York World\'s Fair.
It consists of 39 85acres, featuring rose, bee, herb, wedding, and perennial gardens, an arboretum, an art gallery, and a "Platinum" LEED rated Visitor and Administration Building.
Staten Island’s oldest cultural institution, and the only remaining general interest museum in New York City.

The ferry\'s single route runs 5.2 miles (8.4 km) through New York Harbor between the New York City boroughs of Manhattan and Staten Island, with ferry boats making the trip in approximately 25 minutes.
an 8-acre (3.2 ha) suburban zoo in West New Brighton, Staten Island, New York City.
home to one of the United States\' most extensive collections of Himalayan artifacts.
a 526-acre (213 hectare)[4] public park in the New York City borough of Brooklyn, and the second largest public park in Brooklyn

The Prospect Park Zoo presently offers children\'s educational programs, is engaged in restoration of endangered species populations, runs a wildlife theater and reaches out to the local community through volunteer programs.
The facility occupies 14 acres and boasts 266 species of aquatic wildlife.
a hybrid cable-stayed/suspension bridge in New York City and is one of the oldest roadway bridges in the United States.
On average, the zoo has 2.15 million visitors each year, and it comprises 265 acres (107 ha) of park lands and naturalistic habitats, through which the Bronx River flows.
It serves as the home ballpark for the New York Yankees of Major League Baseball (MLB), and is also the home park for New York City FC of Major League Soccer (MLS).
The museum focuses on contemporary and 20th-century works created by American artists, but it has hosted exhibitions of art and design from Latin America, Africa, and Asia.
the former home of American writer Edgar Allan Poe.
